questions.title: Data Stream Processor (Mean, Median, Mode)
questions.prompt: Implement a class `StreamProcessor` that receives integer data points from a vehicle sensor. It must support `add(num)`, `get_mean()`, `get_median()`, and `get_mode()` in O(log n) time or better per operation.
followups: How do you maintain two heaps to track the median in O(1) retrieval time?
How do you handle the mode when multiple numbers have the same frequency?
What is the memory footprint of your design for billions of readings?
The interviewer pushed back on O(n) mode retrieval. How do you achieve O(1) for get_mode()?

questions.title: Trapping Rain Water (Battery Cooling)
questions.prompt: Given an elevation map representing the cross-section of a battery cooling channel, compute the total amount of water (coolant) that can be trapped after a thermal event. Implement brute force, then optimize to O(n) time with O(1) space.
followups: What is the time complexity of the brute force DP approach?
Explain the intuition behind the two-pointer O(1) space solution.
How would this change if the bars had varying widths?

questions.title: Contiguous Segment Allocator (Memory Management)
questions.prompt: Design an in-memory contiguous segment allocator over an array of `n` cells (indexed 0..n-1), all initially free. Support: 1) `allocate(size) -> index`: allocates the first available contiguous block of `size` cells and returns the start index; returns -1 if no such block exists. 2) `free(index)`: frees the block starting at `index`. Optimize for speed.
followups: What data structures can track free blocks efficiently (e.g., balanced BST, interval map)?
How do you merge adjacent free blocks during `free()`?
What is the time complexity of your `allocate` and `free` operations?
How would you handle fragmentation over time?

questions.title: H2O Molecule Synchronization (Concurrency)
questions.prompt: You are given two kinds of threads: hydrogen and oxygen. Each hydrogen thread calls `releaseHydrogen()`, each oxygen thread calls `releaseOxygen()`. Design a synchronization mechanism that ensures molecules are formed as H2O (two hydrogens, one oxygen) without race conditions or deadlocks.
followups: How do you ensure that exactly two hydrogen threads and one oxygen thread proceed together?
What happens if there is an imbalance of threads (e.g., excess hydrogen)?
How would you implement this using Semaphores vs Monitors?
Can you solve this without using a queue?

questions.title: In-Place Permutation Verification
questions.prompt: Given an integer list `A` of length `n`, determine whether `A` is a permutation of `[0, 1, ..., n-1]`. You must do it in-place with O(1) extra space (no auxiliary arrays or hash sets).
followups: How can you use the array indices themselves to mark visited elements?
What is the risk of using negation to mark visited elements?
How do you handle negative numbers or values out of range?
What is the time complexity of your solution?

questions.title: Minimum Difference Pair (Latency Analysis)
questions.prompt: Given an array of integers representing network latencies, return all increasing pairs `[a, b]` such that `b - a` equals the **minimal absolute difference** between any two elements. The pairs must be sorted by `a` ascending.
followups: What is the brute force O(nÂ²) approach?
How does sorting the array simplify the problem to O(n log n)?
What if there are duplicate values? How do you handle the minimal difference of zero?

questions.title: Fast Power (Exponentiation)
questions.prompt: Implement `pow(x, n)`, which calculates `x` raised to the power `n` (where `n` is a 32-bit integer). Optimize for time complexity.
followups: What is the brute force O(n) approach and its problem?
Explain the divide-and-conquer O(log n) approach.
How do you handle negative exponents?
What edge cases (e.g., n = -2^31) cause overflow and how do you mitigate them?

questions.title: Expression Evaluator (+, -, *, /)
questions.prompt: Given a string `s` containing digits, '+', '-', '*', '/', and spaces, evaluate the expression respecting operator precedence. Do not use built-in eval().
followups: How do you handle the '*' and '/' operators with higher precedence?
What is the time and space complexity?
How would you extend this to support parentheses?

questions.title: RDBMS vs NoSQL Trade-offs
questions.prompt: You are designing the backend for Tesla's vehicle service history. Compare RDBMS (PostgreSQL) and NoSQL (MongoDB/Cassandra). Which would you choose and why?
followups: What are the CAP theorem trade-offs between these systems?
How do you handle schema migrations in a NoSQL database?
Why might you choose a time-series database for telemetry data?

questions.title: Kubernetes: Multi-Tenancy and GitOps
questions.prompt: Describe how you have used Kubernetes in production. How would you handle multi-tenant access control in ArgoCD? What is your rollback strategy when an ArgoCD deployment introduces regressions?
followups: How do you isolate build environments for different vehicle software teams?
How would you debug a Jenkins agent stuck in a Pending state on Kubernetes?
What's your approach to running bare metal nodes under Kubernetes control?

questions.title: Real-Time Vehicle Monitoring (System Design)
questions.prompt: How would you design a real-time monitoring system for millions of Tesla vehicles? Focus on telemetry ingestion, anomaly detection, and low-latency alerting.
followups: What technologies would you choose for ingestion (Kafka vs Kinesis)?
How do you process streaming data to detect anomalies (Flink, Spark Streaming)?
How do you handle missing data or sensor drift?
How do you balance real-time requirements with cost?

questions.title: HTTP Methods: Idempotency and Safety
questions.prompt: Explain the core HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH). Define idempotency and safety. Which methods are idempotent and why?
followups: Why is PUT idempotent but POST is not?
How do you implement an idempotent POST endpoint?
What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?

questions.title: Course Schedule (Dependency Resolution)
questions.prompt: Tesla's firmware build system has dependencies between modules. Given `numModules` and prerequisites `[a, b]` indicating `b` must be built before `a`, determine if you can build all modules.
followups: How do you detect a cycle in a directed graph?
Compare Kahn's algorithm (BFS) vs DFS for topological sorting.
How would you return the actual build order?

questions.title: Group Anagrams (Telemetry Signatures)
questions.prompt: Given an array of telemetry event signatures (strings), group the anagrams together. Anagrams are signatures with the same character frequency.
followups: What is the time complexity of using a sorted string as a key?
How can you optimize using a character count array as a key?
What if the strings are extremely long?

questions.title: Design a Hammock Stand
questions.prompt: How would you design a hammock stand? Walk through your first-principles thinking process.
followups: What are the forces acting on the stand?
What materials would you consider and why?
How do you ensure stability without permanent fixtures?

questions.title: Behavioral: Disagreement with Manager
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you disagreed with your manager or a senior engineer. How did you handle it, and what was the outcome?
followups: How did you prepare your argument?
Were you able to find a compromise?
What did you learn about influencing without authority?
